summary: Maurice Hyman Halperin was a former OSS official and Boston University professor suspected of Soviet espionage and working for the Soviet government. The documents indicate that the CIA and FBI investigated Halperin due to his past activities and associations, including his time in Mexico and connections to individuals potentially involved in espionage. He is connected to investigations into American Communists in Mexico. By 1962, he was residing in Cuba, as indicated by a Christmas card sent from him. His file was reviewed by the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA).
significance: Maurice Halperin's significance in the JFK context stems from the HSCA's review of his file, suggesting a potential, though not explicitly stated, connection to the assassination investigation. His alleged ties to Soviet espionage and activities in Mexico, along with his association with individuals of interest, made him a subject of interest to the HSCA.
